title: Vjekoslav Karas
text:
Vjekoslav Karas (19 May 1821 - 5 July 1858) was a <a href="Croats">Croatian</a> painter, considered a pioneer of a new era of Croatian painting and art in general.
Life.
Born in <a href="Karlovac">Karlovac</a>, <a href="Croatia">Croatia</a>, Karas was sent to be educated in <a href="Italy">Italy</a> in 1938. While in <a href="Rome">Rome</a>, he drew inspiration from <a href="Bible">biblical</a> and religious themes, painting "Mother with Moses on the river bank". While in Italy he developed a love for music and learned to play the <a href="flute">flute</a> and the <a href="guitar">guitar</a> while composing songs in both Italian and Croatian. He began focusing his craft on portraits, painting "Roman woman playing a lute" and "Roman commoner" before returning to Karlovac in 1848. Upon his return, he continued painting portraits and began painting local country life and local folk. He moved to <a href="Zagreb">Zagreb</a> and began teaching. From 1851-18522 he traveled to <a href="Bosnia">Bosnia</a> where he painted a portrait of <a href="Ottoman%20Empire">Ottoman</a> field marshal and governor <a href="Omer-pa%C5%A1a%20Latas">Omer-paša Latas</a> and his daughter.
Karas suffered periodically from depression and had even attempted suicide. He briefly stayed with <a href="bishop">bishop</a> <a href="Josip%20Juraj%20Strossmayer">Josip Juraj Strossmayer</a> in <a href="%C4%90akovo">Đakovo</a>, but left soon after his suicide attempt. Still suffering from depression and living in poverty, Karas committed suicide by drowning in the <a href="Korana">Korana</a> river in his native <a href="Karlovac">Karlovac</a>.
